catalogue.title: Build Your Innovation Engine: Capturing Ideas with an AI-Powered Copilot
catalogue.miniDescription: Make it effortless for any employee to submit their innovative ideas, and for you to capture, track, and action them.
catalogue.problem: Meet Sarah, an engineer in the field service team. From her daily interactions, she has a fantastic idea for a product modification that would save customers hours of maintenance. But how does she submit it? There's no formal process. She considers sending an email to the generic "product team" address but assumes it will just get lost. Discouraged by the friction, she gives up, and a potentially game-changing idea vanishes.
catalogue.value: Your employees are your greatest source of innovation. They see the daily problems, understand customer frustrations, and have brilliant ideas for product improvements and new features. The tragedy is that most of these ideas are never heard; they get lost in passing conversations or die in an email inbox. This guide will show you how to build a simple but powerful "Innovation Engine" that makes it effortless for anyone in your company to submit, and for you to capture, the next big idea.
catalogue.roi: The return here is not about cost savings, but about value creation and cultural change. A = Number of high-value ideas captured per year that would otherwise have been lost. B = Average potential revenue or cost-saving value of a single successful idea. C = The strategic value of fostering a company-wide culture of innovation. Formula: Potential Annual Value = (A * B) * (Average Idea Success Rate %) + Cultural Impact (C) Example: Even if this system captures only one successful, high-value idea per year (A=1) that generates €250,000 in new revenue (B), the system has paid for itself many times over. The long-term value of making every employee feel like a valued contributor is immense.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Pure Generative Action Approach

This use case is a perfect Tier 1 scenario, designed to lower the barrier to entry for innovation as much as possible. An employee with an idea will express it naturally and conversationally. The core task is for the AI to understand this unstructured input and intelligently extract the key components of the idea. A rigid, form-like Topic would feel bureaucratic and stifle the very creativity we want to encourage.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Prepare Your Foundation (The Idea Hub): Create a central repository for all ideas. A SharePoint list is the perfect starting point. Create columns for Title, Submitter, ProblemStatement, ProposedSolution, CustomerBenefit, Status, and ProductLine.
  2. Build the Capture Engine (The Power Automate Plugin): In Power Automate, create a new flow triggered by "Run from Copilot."
    • Plugin Name: Capture New Product Idea
    • Description for AI: "Use this to capture a new product idea or an improvement suggestion from an employee. It requires a title for the idea, a description of the problem it solves, the proposed solution, and the customer benefit."
    • Inputs: Define text inputs for IdeaTitle, ProblemStatement, ProposedSolution, and CustomerBenefit.
    • Flow Logic: Use the SharePoint "Create item" action to log the idea. Use a Switch control to check for keywords and route a notification to the relevant product manager in Teams. Send a confirmation back to the submitter.
  3. Enable the Plugin in Copilot Studio: Simply navigate to the Plugins section in your company-wide Copilot, find your new plugin, and switch it on.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Close the feedback loop to supercharge engagement. Create a second, separate Power Automate flow triggered "When an item is modified" on your SharePoint list. Configure it to run only when the Status column changes. The flow then sends a notification to the original Submitter, letting them know the status of their idea has been updated. This simple act of providing feedback is incredibly powerful for encouraging future submissions.

catalogue.title: From Request to Receipt: Automating the Purchase Order Lifecycle
catalogue.miniDescription: Streamline the entire PO process, from a guided request in a Power App to automated approvals and ERP integration.
catalogue.problem: An office manager, David, needs to order new monitors for the design team. He fills out a PO request form in Excel, gets his department head to sign a printed copy, scans it, and emails it to the finance department. The finance team then has to manually key the information into the ERP system to generate the official PO number. The whole process is slow, opaque, and requires manual work from at least three different people.
catalogue.value: The Purchase Order (PO) process is the backbone of corporate spending. It's how every department, from marketing to maintenance, buys the goods and services they need to operate. Yet, this fundamental process is often a slow, manual workflow of filling out forms, chasing email approvals, and manually creating records in the finance system. This guide will show you how to build a streamlined, automated PO system that accelerates purchasing, enforces financial controls, and provides complete visibility from request to receipt.
catalogue.roi: The return is measured in accelerated procurement cycles and improved financial controls. A = Average time saved per PO request across all staff involved (requester, approvers, finance). B = Number of POs processed per month. C = Average fully-loaded hourly cost of the staff involved. Formula: Monthly Savings = (A * B / 60) * C Example: If you save 30 minutes of manual work per PO (A), and your company processes 400 POs a month (B), at a blended staff cost of €50/hour (C), you save 200 hours and **€10,000 every month**. This also provides a perfect audit trail and ensures purchasing policies are always followed.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Hybrid Approach

A PO request is a formal financial document. The submission must be structured to capture critical data like vendor details, line items, quantities, and prices with 100% accuracy. A Power App provides the ideal, form-based interface for this. The backend approval workflow, which must route to different managers based on the total cost, is a complex orchestration perfect for a powerful Power Automate flow.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Prepare Your Foundation (Approval Matrix & Dataverse): In Dataverse or a SharePoint list, create your financial approval rules. Columns should include Department, MinAmount, MaxAmount, and RequiredApprover. Create a "PurchaseRequests" table to log every submission.
  2. Build the Submission Interface (The Power App): Create a user-friendly canvas app for submitting PO requests. Use galleries for vendor selection and line items. The "Submit" button will trigger your Power Automate flow.
  3. Create the Procurement Engine (The Power Automate Flow): Create a new flow using the "PowerApps (V2)" trigger.
    • Flow Logic: Log the request in Dataverse. Use the Office 365 Users "Get manager (V2)" action and send an approval card via Teams. Use a Condition to check the total amount and route for higher-level approval if needed. After final approval, create the PO in the ERP and email it to the vendor.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Automate the final step: Goods Receipt. Enhance the Power App with a "Mark as Received" button. When the physical goods arrive, the original requester can find their PO in the app and hit the button. This triggers another simple Power Automate flow that updates the status in the ERP system to "Goods Received," which can then automatically notify the Accounts Payable team that the corresponding invoice is now approved for payment.

catalogue.title: The End of "Where Do I Find?": Building an Instant-Answer HR Policy Bot
catalogue.miniDescription: Build an intelligent HR Copilot that provides instant, accurate answers 24/7, freeing up your HR team for more strategic work.
catalogue.problem: An employee, Maria, wants to know the company's policy on parental leave. She spends ten minutes searching the company intranet with no luck. Frustrated, she sends an email to the general HR inbox. An HR generalist spends another ten minutes finding the right policy document and emailing it back to her. This simple question has consumed 20 minutes of company time and created a frustrating experience for Maria.
catalogue.value: Every HR department is a library of critical information, from vacation policies and expense guidelines to benefits information and company procedures. The problem is that employees can never find what they need. They end up asking the same questions over and over, turning your highly skilled HR Business Partners into human search engines. This guide will show you how to build an intelligent HR Copilot that provides instant, accurate answers 24/7, freeing up your HR team for more strategic, high-value work.
catalogue.roi: The return is measured in deflected queries and reclaimed time for your HR team. A = Number of routine policy questions asked per month. B = Average time an HR professional spends answering one question (in minutes). C = Average fully-loaded hourly cost of an HR professional. Formula: Monthly Savings = (A * B / 60) * C Example: If your HR team fields 400 policy questions a month (A), and each one takes 5 minutes to handle (B), at a staff cost of €60/hour (C), you save over 33 hours and **€2,000 every month**. More importantly, you give your employees instant answers and free your HR team to focus on culture, talent development, and other strategic initiatives.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Pure Generative Action Approach

This is the quintessential use case for a knowledge-base AI, making it a perfect Tier 1 scenario. Employee questions are unpredictable and phrased in countless ways. A scripted Topic would never cover all these variations. The core task is for the AI to understand the user's natural language question and find the relevant information within a trusted knowledge base. This is precisely what Generative Answers are designed for.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Prepare Your Foundation (The Knowledge Hub): Your AI is only as good as the information you give it. Create a SharePoint site to act as your single source of truth for all HR policies and FAQs. Ensure the content is well-structured, with clear headings and simple language.
  2. Build the AI Brain (Configure Generative Answers): In Copilot Studio, create a new Copilot. Navigate to the Generative AI section. In the "Websites" input box, enter the URL of the SharePoint site you created in Step 1. Adjust the content moderation settings to your desired level.
  3. Test and Deploy: Use the test pane in Copilot Studio to ask it questions you know are in your documents. Once you are satisfied, you can deploy it to Microsoft Teams or other channels with a single click.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Use the Copilot's analytics to drive continuous improvement. Once your Copilot is live, review the conversation transcripts in the Analytics section of Copilot Studio. Look for questions that the Copilot couldn't answer. This is free, actionable feedback! Use this data to identify gaps in your knowledge base. If ten people ask about the "work from home" policy and get no answer, you know you need to create that document and add it to your SharePoint site.

catalogue.title: The End of Manual Entry: Processing Invoices with AI Builder & Power Automate
catalogue.miniDescription: Build a powerful, automated engine that reads, understands, and processes invoices from an email inbox into your ERP system.
catalogue.problem: Meet Ben, an AP clerk. His entire morning is dedicated to the invoices@ inbox. He opens an email, downloads a PDF, and then carefully types the vendor name, invoice number, date, and line-item amounts into the company's ERP system. He does this dozens, if not hundreds, of times a day. It's a recipe for burnout, data entry errors, and delayed payments.
catalogue.value: For any Accounts Payable (AP) department, the relentless flow of invoices is a daily reality. These invoices arrive as PDF attachments in a seemingly endless stream of emails. The traditional process of manually opening each file, keying the data into an ERP system, and routing it for approval is one of the most time-consuming, repetitive, and error-prone tasks in any finance department. This guide will show you how to build a powerful, automated engine that reads, understands, and processes invoices for you.
catalogue.roi: The return here is one of the easiest to calculate and one of the most significant in any automation program. A = Average time to manually process one invoice (in minutes). B = Number of invoices processed per month. C = Average fully-loaded hourly cost of an AP clerk. Formula: Monthly Savings = ((A * B) / 60) * C Example: If manual processing takes 10 minutes (A), you process 1,500 invoices a month (B), at a staff cost of €40/hour (C), you save 250 hours and **€10,000 every single month**. This allows your AP team to focus on higher-value activities like vendor management and cash flow analysis.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Backend Engine with Human-in-the-Loop

This is not a Copilot use case. It is a pure backend automation workflow driven by an event (an incoming email). The intelligence comes from AI Builder's pre-trained ability to understand the layout and content of invoices, not from a conversational AI.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Prepare Your Foundation (AI Builder & Allocation Rules): The pre-built AI Builder Invoice Processing model is a fantastic starting point. You simply need to add it as an action in your flow.
  2. Build the Processing Engine (The Power Automate Flow): Create a new Automated cloud flow with the "When a new email arrives (V3)" trigger.
    • Flow Logic: Use the AI Builder "Extract information from invoices" action. Look up the corresponding Purchase Order in the ERP. Use a Condition to perform a "2-way match." If it matches, send an approval request. If not, flag for manual review. After approval, post the invoice to the ERP.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Go for the "3-Way Match." Enhance your flow: after looking up the PO, add another step to query your warehouse management system (WMS) or ERP to confirm that the goods on the PO have actually been received. Only send the invoice for final approval if the PO matches and the goods have been marked as received. This eliminates the risk of paying for items that haven't arrived yet and represents a best-in-class financial control process.

catalogue.title: From Reminder to Revenue: Automating Client Contract Renewals
catalogue.miniDescription: Build a "Renewal Assistant" that proactively alerts your sales team to expiring contracts and drafts outreach emails automatically.
catalogue.problem: Meet Maria, a top-performing Account Manager. Her success is built on relationships, but a significant part of her week is spent on administrative drudgery. She has to manually log into a legacy server (the "MCP Server") to check a list of her clients' contract expiry dates. She then creates calendar reminders for herself and, when the time comes, manually drafts outreach emails. Last quarter, she was on vacation, and a key client's contract renewal was missed, putting a significant account at risk.
catalogue.value: In any business with recurring revenue, the contract renewal is the moment that matters most. It's the key to predictable income and long-term growth. Yet, the process for managing these renewals is often a manual, high-risk scramble. Account Managers waste precious time hunting through systems for expiry dates and copy-pasting email templates, creating a process ripe for human error and missed opportunities. This guide will show you how to build an automated "Renewal Assistant" that acts as a proactive wingman for your sales team, ensuring no contract ever slips through the cracks.
catalogue.roi: The return is measured in reclaimed time for your sales team and, more importantly, protected revenue. A = Time saved per renewal outreach by an Account Manager (in minutes). B = Number of renewals managed per month. C = Average fully-loaded hourly cost of an Account Manager. D = The annual value of renewals that are not missed or delayed due to human error. Formula: Monthly Operational Savings = (A * B / 60) * C Value Proposition = Operational Savings + Revenue Protection (D) Example: If you save 20 minutes per renewal (A) for a team that manages 100 renewals a month (B), at a staff cost of €75/hour (C), you save over 33 hours and **€2,500 per month**. The value of preventing even one large contract from lapsing (D) could be tens of thousands of euros.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Backend Engine with Human-in-the-Loop

This is a classic backend automation designed to proactively push critical information to your team and simplify their response. The core workflow is not conversational. It's a scheduled process that runs in the background, triggered by time, not by a user's query. It's a perfect example of an automated engine that empowers employees by bringing the right information to them at the right time, directly within their workflow in Microsoft Teams.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Prepare Your Foundation (API, Template, and Contacts): You need a stable, documented API for your custom server that allows you to query for contracts based on an expiry date range. Create your ideal renewal outreach email. You can store the HTML body in a SharePoint list for easy updating without changing the flow, or create a .eml file in OneDrive. Ensure your Account Managers' contact data for their clients is up-to-date in Outlook or your primary CRM (like Dataverse).
  2. Build the Proactive Engine (The Power Automate Flow): In Power Automate, create a new Scheduled cloud flow and set the Recurrence to run weekly. Use the HTTP action to get expiring contracts from your server's API. Use "Parse JSON" to process the data. Loop through each contract and use the Teams "Post adaptive card and wait for a response" action to notify the Account Manager.
  3. Handle the Button Click: Add a Condition to check if the "Draft Renewal Email" button was clicked. If YES, use Outlook actions to find the client's contact and then "Create draft email (V2)", populating it with dynamic content from your template.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Create a companion Generative Action plugin for on-demand inquiries. The main flow pushes information weekly, but what if an Account Manager wants to check a contract right now? Plugin Name: Get Client Contract Status. Description for AI: "Finds the expiry date, value, and status for any client contract using the client's name." The plugin takes ClientName as an input, calls the same MCP Server API, and returns the details. Now, Maria can simply ask her Copilot, "What's the status of the Global Corp contract?" and get an instant answer.

catalogue.title: HR Policy & FAQ Bot
catalogue.miniDescription: Provide a 24/7 self-service Copilot that empowers employees to get instant answers to HR questions, freeing up HR professionals for more strategic work.
catalogue.problem: An employee wants to know the company policy on working from abroad. They email their HR business partner, who is in meetings and doesn't reply for a day. The employee gets a delayed answer to a simple question, and the HR professional loses time that could have been spent on talent management or employee relations.
catalogue.value: The HR department is a constant hub of activity, answering the same questions day after day about payroll, leave policies, benefits, and company procedures. This solution provides a 24/7 self-service Copilot that empowers employees to get instant answers, freeing up HR professionals for more strategic work.
catalogue.roi: The return is measured in reclaimed productivity across the entire organization. A = Average time saved per employee per week by getting instant answers. B = Number of employees in the agency. C = Average fully-loaded hourly cost of an employee. Formula: Annual Productivity Gain = A * B * 52 * C Example: If you save each of your 1,000 employees (B) just 15 minutes per week (A=0.25 hours) at a blended cost of €40/hour (C), you reclaim 13,000 hours of productive time and **€520,000 in value every year**.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Pure Generative Action Approach

This is the quintessential Tier 1: Generative Action First Copilot, built on a curated knowledge base.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Curate the Knowledge Base: Work with HR to ensure all current, approved policy documents are in one place. This is the most critical step for accuracy.
  2. Configure the Copilot: In Copilot Studio, create a new Copilot. In the "Generative AI" section, add the SharePoint site URL as a knowledge source. Customize the system prompt to define its persona and limitations (e.g., "You are the friendly HR Assistant. You only answer based on official documents. You cannot give personal advice. Always cite your source.").
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Use the Copilot to initiate workflows. After answering a question about parental leave, the Copilot could ask, "Would you like to apply for parental leave?" If the user says yes, it can trigger a Power Automate flow that starts the official leave request and approval process, creating a seamless transition from information gathering to action.

catalogue.title: New Employee Onboarding
catalogue.miniDescription: Automate and orchestrate the entire onboarding checklist to ensure a seamless day-one experience for every new hire.
catalogue.problem: A new marketing manager is hired. The hiring manager is busy and forgets to request access to the company's CRM system. On her first day, the new hire can't access key tools and feels unproductive and unwelcome. Meanwhile, IT and HR are chasing the manager for required paperwork.
catalogue.value: A structured and welcoming onboarding process is proven to increase employee retention and accelerate their time to productivity. This cross-industry solution automates the entire onboarding checklist, ensuring no task is forgotten and providing a seamless day-one experience for every new hire.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in retention and productivity. Formula: Value = (Value of Increased Retention) + (Value of Faster Time-to-Productivity) Example: Ensures a consistent and professional onboarding experience for every new employee, which is proven to improve long-term retention. Reduces the risk of missed security or compliance steps. Frees up significant administrative time for HR and managers. Gets new employees productive faster.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: An Orchestration Workflow

This is a time-based orchestration workflow managed by Power Automate.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Map the Process: Work with all involved departments to map out the ideal onboarding timeline and checklist.
  2. Create a Tracking List: In SharePoint, create a list to log all onboarding tasks, with columns for New Hire Name, Task Description, Assigned To, Due Date, and Status.
  3. Build the Flow: Trigger the flow when the new hire form is submitted. Use Delay until actions to schedule tasks for the future (e.g., delay until 7 days before the start date). Use connectors for Planner (Create a task), Outlook (Send an email), and Teams (Post a message) to assign work and send notifications. Use the SharePoint Create item action to log every task in your tracking list.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Create a "buddy" system. As part of the flow, use an AI Builder prompt to analyze the new hire's profile (department, interests if available) and suggest 3 potential onboarding "buddies" from the employee directory. The manager can then select one, and the flow automatically schedules a 30-minute introductory coffee meeting between the new hire and their buddy in their first week.

catalogue.title: Employee Offboarding
catalogue.miniDescription: Ensure a secure, compliant, and efficient offboarding for every departing employee with an automated checklist and access revocation workflow.
catalogue.problem: An employee resigns. Their manager forgets to inform IT until the employee's last day. IT scrambles to disable their account, but they miss revoking access to a third-party SaaS application. The ex-employee retains access to company data for a month after leaving.
catalogue.value: When an employee leaves, a series of critical actions must be taken immediately to protect company assets and security. A manual offboarding process risks sensitive data exposure and can create a poor final impression on the departing employee. This automation ensures a secure, compliant, and efficient offboarding every time.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is almost entirely in risk mitigation. Formula: Value = (Cost of a Security Breach Averted) + (Compliance Audit Value) Example: This automation prevents data breaches and protects intellectual property by ensuring access is revoked promptly and completely. It provides a clear, auditable record that is invaluable for compliance and security audits.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Security-Critical Orchestration

This is a security-critical orchestration workflow.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Map the Process: Work with IT Security and HR to define the non-negotiable offboarding steps and their timing.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger from the resignation form submission. Use a Delay until action to schedule the main actions to run at a specific time on the employee's last day (e.g., 5:01 PM). Use the Azure AD actions Update user (to disable the account) and Remove member from group. Use connectors for your IT ticketing and payroll systems.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Automate knowledge transfer. Before the de-provisioning steps, the flow can send a task to the departing employee's manager: "Please confirm that [Employee Name]'s project files have been transferred to [New Owner]." The offboarding flow will not proceed until the manager has checked a box to confirm that this critical knowledge transfer has occurred.

catalogue.title: IT Helpdesk Tier 1 Support
catalogue.miniDescription: Deploy an AI-powered Tier 1 support agent to instantly resolve common IT issues like printer problems and VPN connection failures.
catalogue.problem: An employee can't connect to the office printer. They create a ticket in ServiceNow. A technician is assigned, who then messages the employee and walks them through the standard troubleshooting steps (checking the driver, restarting the spooler service). The entire process takes 30 minutes for a 2-minute fix.
catalogue.value: A significant portion of IT helpdesk tickets are for common, easily solvable problems: printer issues, VPN connection problems, software installation queries. This Copilot acts as a Tier 1 support agent, resolving these issues instantly and freeing up human technicians to focus on complex incidents.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in direct cost savings and employee productivity. A = Average time spent by a technician on a simple Tier 1 ticket (in minutes). B = Number of Tier 1 tickets deflected or resolved by the Copilot per month. C = Hourly cost of an IT technician. Formula: Monthly Savings = (A * B / 60) * C Example: If a ticket takes 15 minutes (0.25 hours) (A), and the bot handles 1,000 tickets a month (B) for a technician costing $45/hr (C), the savings are (0.25 * 1000) * 45 = $11,250 per month. It also provides a much faster resolution time for employees.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Hybrid Tier 2 Approach

This solution uses guided Topics for troubleshooting combined with Power Automate plugins to interact with IT systems.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Document Solutions: Work with the helpdesk team to document the standard troubleshooting steps for the top 5-10 most common issues.
  2. Build the Copilot Topics: In Copilot Studio, create a separate Topic for each issue. Use a combination of Question, Message, and Action nodes to build the conversational flow.
  3. Create the Plugins: Build Power Automate flows to perform automated actions, like restarting a service or checking a system's status.
  4. Configure Escalation: At the end of each topic, use the ServiceNow connector's Create a record action to create a ticket if the issue isn't resolved.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Integrate with an IT asset management database. When an employee starts a chat, the Copilot can first look up their user ID and find the asset number of their assigned laptop. It can then use an AI Builder prompt to generate a health check summary based on device data (e.g., disk space, last reboot time) to provide a more intelligent and context-aware support experience.

catalogue.title: Password Reset
catalogue.miniDescription: Provide a secure, 24/7 self-service portal for employees to reset their own passwords without any human intervention from IT.
catalogue.problem: An employee returns from vacation and has forgotten their Windows password. They can't log in to create a ticket. They have to call the helpdesk, verbally verify their identity (e.g., by providing their employee number and manager's name), and then wait for the technician to reset their password and provide a temporary one over the phone.
catalogue.value: It is the single most common IT request in any organization. Manually handling password resets is a pure, low-value cost for the IT helpdesk. This solution provides a secure, self-service way for employees to reset their own passwords, 24/7, without any human intervention.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is a direct reduction in IT helpdesk workload. Formula: Monthly Savings = (Time per Reset in minutes / 60) * Resets per Month * Technician Hourly Cost Example: If a password reset takes a technician 10 minutes and you have 300 resets a month, that's 50 hours of IT time saved every month. It also allows employees to solve their own problem instantly, at any time of day or night.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Secure Self-Service Workflow

This solution uses a Power Automate flow with the Azure AD connector, exposed via a secure interface.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Configure SSPR: The prerequisite is that Microsoft Self-Service Password Reset is properly configured in your Azure AD tenant, and users have registered their authentication methods (e.g., the Authenticator app).
  2. Build the Portal: Create a simple, single-purpose Power Pages site.
  3. Build the Flow: The flow itself is simple. The main logic is handled by the SSPR process. The flow's job is to initiate it. Use the Azure AD connector. Note that password reset actions require specific, elevated permissions for the service principal, which must be carefully managed.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Handle account lockouts. Expand the solution to handle account lockouts. The flow can check the status of the user's account in Azure AD. If it's locked, it can present an option to unlock it (after multi-factor authentication), providing a single portal for the two most common account access issues.

catalogue.title: Software Access Request
catalogue.miniDescription: Automate the entire request, approval, and provisioning workflow for new software applications.
catalogue.problem: A new analyst needs access to Power BI Pro. She emails her manager. The manager forwards the email to the IT helpdesk. The helpdesk creates a ticket, then emails the manager back to get formal approval. Once approved, the technician assigns the license. The process involves multiple emails and takes over a day.
catalogue.value: Employees frequently need access to new software applications to do their jobs. This process often requires manager approval and sometimes license checks before IT can grant access. This solution automates the entire request, approval, and provisioning workflow.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in speed and license management. Formula: Value = (Productivity Gain from Faster Access) + (Cost Savings from License Reclamation) Example: Speeds up the process of getting employees the tools they need. Provides a simple, user-friendly experience. Ensures proper manager approval is obtained and audited for every software request. Helps with license management by providing a clear record of who requested and was assigned each license.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Request and Approval Automation

This is a classic request and approval automation.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Build the Power App: Create a canvas app that displays your company's software catalog. You can store the catalog in a SharePoint list.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger the flow from the Power App. Use the Get user profile (V2) action to find the requester's manager. Use the Start and wait for an approval action. Use the Microsoft 365 Admin connector's Assign license action. You will need to know the specific SKU for the license you want to assign.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Automate license reclamation. Create a scheduled flow that runs quarterly. It can check for users who have a specific license (e.g., Visio) but have not used the application in the last 90 days (by checking sign-in logs in Azure AD). The flow can then automatically send a notification to the user asking if they still need the license. If they say no, or don't respond, the license can be automatically un-assigned and returned to the pool, saving significant software licensing costs.

catalogue.title: Purchase Order (PO) Creation & Approval
catalogue.miniDescription: Digitize and automate the entire PO workflow, from request and dynamic approvals to vendor communication.
catalogue.problem: A department manager needs to order new laptops. They fill out a paper PO request form, sign it, and then walk it over to the finance department. The finance team has to get the IT director's signature, and then manually key the PO into the accounting system before emailing it to the vendor.
catalogue.value: The process of creating a purchase order, getting it approved by the correct budget holder, and sending it to a vendor is a universal business process that is often manual and paper-based. This solution digitizes and automates the entire PO workflow.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in process acceleration and financial control. Formula: Annual Savings = (Time Saved per PO * POs per Year * Staff Hourly Cost) Example: Drastically accelerates the procurement cycle. Provides complete visibility into the status of any PO. Enforces financial controls and approval policies with 100% consistency. Creates a full digital audit trail of all purchasing activity.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Dynamic Approval Workflow

This is a dynamic approval workflow.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Define the Approval Matrix: Store your company's approval limits in a SharePoint list or Dataverse table so they can be changed without editing the flow.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger from the Power App or SharePoint. Use Condition or Switch controls to check the PO amount and determine the approval path. Use a series of Start and wait for an approval actions for the sequential approvals. Use the Populate a Microsoft Word template and Convert Word Document to PDF actions to generate the final PO document. Use the Send an email (V2) action to send the PDF to the vendor.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Implement 3-way matching. When the vendor sends their invoice, a separate AP Automation flow (see Use Case 78) can automatically match the invoice against the original purchase order in this system and the goods receipt record from the warehouse system. If all three documents match, the invoice can be approved for payment without any human intervention.

catalogue.title: Invoice Processing (AP Automation)
catalogue.miniDescription: Use AI to automate the process of receiving, reading, and routing vendor invoices for approval and payment.
catalogue.problem: A vendor emails an invoice as a PDF to the general accounts@company.com inbox. An AP clerk has to open the PDF, manually key the invoice number, date, amount, and line items into the accounting system, and then email the invoice to the correct department head for approval.
catalogue.value: Accounts Payable (AP) is one of the most time-consuming, manual, and paper-intensive functions in any finance department. This solution uses AI to automate the process of receiving, reading, and routing vendor invoices for approval and payment.
catalogue.roi: The return here is one of the easiest to calculate and one of the most significant in any automation program. A = Average time to manually process one invoice (in minutes). B = Number of invoices per month. C = Cost of an AP clerk per hour. Formula: Monthly Savings = (A * B / 60) * C Example: If manual processing takes 10 minutes (0.167 hours) (A), and the company processes 2,000 invoices a month (B) with staff costing $40/hr (C), the savings are (0.167 * 2000) * 40 = $13,360 per month. This also allows the company to capture early payment discounts and avoid late fees.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A High-ROI Workflow

This solution combines AI and workflow automation.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Use AI Builder: The pre-built invoice processing model in AI Builder is highly effective and requires minimal training.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger the flow from a dedicated email inbox. Use AI Builder to extract invoice details. Add logic to determine the correct approver (e.g., by looking up the vendor in a SharePoint list or by matching a PO number). Use the Start and wait for an approval action. Use the appropriate connector to create the final invoice record in your ERP.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Automate vendor onboarding. Before you can pay an invoice, the vendor needs to be set up in your system. Create a separate workflow where a new vendor can submit their details (company name, address, bank details) via a Power Pages portal. This flow can route the new vendor for internal approval and, once approved, automatically create the vendor record in your ERP, ensuring the data is correct from the start.

catalogue.title: Meeting Room Booking
catalogue.miniDescription: Deploy a smart assistant to handle all aspects of meeting room booking, from finding available rooms to sending invitations.
catalogue.problem: An employee needs to book a room for a 4-person project meeting tomorrow morning with a whiteboard and a conference phone. They have to open Outlook calendar, use the "Room Finder" tool, manually check the availability of a dozen different rooms, and check the attributes of each one to see if it meets their requirements.
catalogue.value: Finding and booking a suitable meeting room, especially in a large office with high demand, can be a frustrating and time-consuming experience. This solution provides a conversational Copilot that acts as a smart assistant to handle all aspects of meeting room booking.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in employee time saved. Formula: Annual Savings = (Time Saved per Booking * Bookings per Day * Work Days * Hourly Employee Cost) Example: Saves employees time and frustration every day. Improves the utilization of office resources by making it easier to find and book the right space. Reduces scheduling conflicts.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Tier 1 Generative Action First Copilot

This Copilot interacts with Microsoft 365 services.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Room Configuration: Ensure your meeting rooms are set up correctly as "Room Resources" in your Microsoft 365 admin center, with their capacity and features (whiteboard, projector, etc.) properly tagged.
  2. Build the Plugins: Create a "Find Room" flow using the Microsoft Graph API's findMeetingTimes endpoint. Create a "Book Room" flow using the createEvent endpoint.
  3. Configure the Copilot: Add the two flows as Plugins in Copilot Studio. The descriptive names and inputs will allow the Copilot's generative AI to understand how and when to use them.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Integrate catering and equipment requests. After booking the room, the Copilot could ask, "Do you require any catering or special IT equipment for this meeting?" If the user says yes, it could trigger another flow that sends a request to the facilities or IT department, creating a complete, end-to-end meeting setup service.

catalogue.title: Travel Request & Approval
catalogue.miniDescription: Automate the entire travel request and approval workflow, ensuring compliance with company policy before booking.
catalogue.problem: An employee needs to book a flight to a conference in Berlin. They have to fill out a Word document, get their manager to sign it, and then email it to the central travel desk. The travel desk then has to confirm that the trip is within budget before giving the employee the approval to book.
catalogue.value: Business travel often requires pre-approval, especially for international trips or expenses exceeding a certain threshold. This process, managed via email, can be slow and difficult to track. This solution automates the entire travel request and approval workflow, ensuring compliance with company policy.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in compliance and efficiency. Formula: Value = (Cost of Non-Compliant Bookings Avoided) + (Admin Hours Saved * Hourly Cost) Example: Enforces travel policy compliance before costs are incurred. Provides a clear and efficient approval process for employees. Creates a complete digital audit trail for all travel expenses. Gives the finance department better visibility and control over the travel budget.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Multi-Step Approval Workflow

This is a multi-step approval and data-gathering workflow.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Store Policies: Create a SharePoint list to store your travel policy data (e.g., per diem limits by city) so the app and flow can reference it.
  2. Build the Power App: Create a canvas app with a clear form. Use rules and formulas to provide the real-time policy feedback.
  3. Build the Flow: Trigger from the Power App. Use the Start and wait for an approval action for the manager's approval. Use a Condition to check the total cost. If it's high, use a second approval action for the department head. Use Send an email (V2) actions to send the final confirmations.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Integrate risk management. Before routing for approval, the flow could call an external API from a travel risk provider (like International SOS). If the destination is currently flagged as high-risk, the flow can add a special third level of approval from the corporate security department, ensuring the company fulfills its duty of care obligations to its employees.

catalogue.title: Contract Lifecycle Management (CLM)
catalogue.miniDescription: Automate and provide visibility into the entire contract lifecycle, from drafting and negotiation to approval, execution, and renewal.
catalogue.problem: A procurement manager needs to create a new contract for a software vendor. She finds an old contract on a shared drive to use as a template, emails it to the legal department for review, and then emails it back and forth with the vendor during negotiations. There is no central visibility on the contract's status, and its renewal date is only tracked in her personal calendar.
catalogue.value: Every organization manages a large number of contracts with vendors, customers, and partners. The contract lifecycle—from drafting and negotiation to approval, execution, and renewal—is a complex process fraught with risk if managed manually. This solution automates and provides visibility into the entire lifecycle.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in risk mitigation and efficiency. Formula: Value = (Value of Missed Renewals Avoided) + (Legal & Admin Hours Saved * Hourly Cost) Example: Mitigates legal and financial risk by ensuring only approved templates and clauses are used. Provides complete visibility into the status of all contracts across the enterprise. Prevents missed renewals, which can lead to service disruptions or unfavorable terms. Saves thousands of hours of administrative and legal time.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Comprehensive Workflow

This is a comprehensive solution combining a central repository, document generation, and approval workflows.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Set up SharePoint: Create document libraries for templates, in-process contracts, and executed contracts. Use rich metadata columns to track status, owner, value, and key dates.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger from a Power App. Use the Word Online connector to generate the draft. Use the Start and wait for an approval action for internal review. Use the Adobe Sign or DocuSign connector to manage the external signature process. Use AI Builder's Extract information from documents model to read the end date from the final PDF. Use the Planner connector to create the renewal reminder.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Create a "Clause Library." Store pre-approved, standard legal clauses in a SharePoint list. In the Power App, allow the user to select and insert these optional clauses into the contract before it's generated. This gives business users flexibility while maintaining legal control over the language used.

catalogue.title: Document Generation & Distribution
catalogue.miniDescription: Automate the generation and distribution of any templated document, from sales quotes to project status reports.
catalogue.problem: A salesperson needs to send a quote to a potential client. They open a previous quote in Word, use "Save As," and then manually replace the client's name, address, line items, and prices by copying data from the CRM. They sometimes make a copy-paste error, sending a quote with the wrong price.
catalogue.value: Many business processes culminate in the creation of a standardized document: a sales quote, a project status report, a client welcome letter. Manually creating these documents by copying and pasting data is slow and error-prone. This solution automates the generation and distribution of any templated document.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in time saved and error reduction. Formula: Annual Savings = (Time Saved per Document * Documents per Year * Staff Hourly Cost) + (Cost of Errors Avoided) Example: Saves time and eliminates embarrassing (and potentially costly) data entry errors. Ensures all customer-facing documents are professional, consistently branded, and accurate. Can be adapted for a huge variety of use cases across the business.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Flexible Workflow

This is a flexible workflow that can be triggered from any system.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Create the Word Template: In Microsoft Word, create your quote template. Use the Developer tab to insert Plain Text Content Controls as placeholders for your dynamic data (e.g., ClientName, TotalAmount).
  2. Build the Flow: Use the Dataverse trigger When a row is selected. Use the Get a row by ID action to get all the details from the triggering record. Use the Word Online Populate a Microsoft Word template action, mapping the data from your CRM to the placeholders in the template. Use the Convert Word Document to PDF action. Use the Outlook Create a draft email (V2) action.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Automate the follow-up. After creating the draft email, the flow can also create a task in the CRM for the salesperson, due in 3 days, with the subject "Follow up on Quote for [Client Name]." This ensures that no sales opportunity is forgotten after the initial quote is sent.

catalogue.title: Employee Recognition & Rewards
catalogue.miniDescription: Create a simple, visible, and automated system for peer-to-peer and manager-to-employee recognition to boost morale and engagement.
catalogue.problem: A team completes a difficult project successfully. The manager wants to recognize their hard work but forgets to mention it in the next all-hands meeting. The team feels their extra effort went unnoticed.
catalogue.value: Recognizing and celebrating employee contributions is a key driver of engagement and a positive company culture. A manual, ad-hoc recognition process often feels inconsistent and can miss deserving employees. This solution provides a simple, visible, and automated way for peer-to-peer and manager-to-employee recognition.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in employee engagement and retention. Formula: Value = (Value of Increased Employee Retention) + (Productivity Gains from Higher Morale) Example: This is an investment in company culture. It boosts morale, improves employee engagement, and reinforces desired behaviors. It provides a simple, equitable, and visible platform for celebrating success, which can have a significant impact on employee retention.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Communication and Tracking Workflow

This solution uses a combination of a simple input form and automated communication.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Create the Form: Build a Microsoft Form for nominations.
  2. Build the Flow: Trigger from When a new response is submitted. Use Get response details and Get user profile (V2) to get information about the nominator and the nominee (including their manager). Use the Start and wait for an approval action. Use the Teams Post message in a chat or channel action. Use an Adaptive Card for a visually appealing post. Use the SharePoint Update item action to add points to the rewards tracker.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Gamify it. Create a Power BI dashboard that visualizes the recognition data. Show leaderboards for the most recognized employees, the managers who give the most recognition, and the company values that are recognized most often. This can create a fun, competitive spirit and provide valuable insights into the company culture.

catalogue.title: Document Review & Approval
catalogue.miniDescription: Provide a structured and auditable review workflow for internal documents, from marketing briefs to technical specifications.
catalogue.problem: A project manager writes a project charter document. She attaches it to an email and sends it to five stakeholders for their review and approval. She receives five separate emails back with conflicting feedback and has no easy way to know if everyone has officially signed off.
catalogue.value: Many internal documents, from marketing briefs to technical specifications, require review and approval from multiple stakeholders before they can be finalized. Managing this process over email leads to version control chaos and a lack of clarity on who has approved what. This solution provides a structured and auditable review workflow.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in process efficiency and compliance. Formula: Value = (Hours Saved per Review Cycle * Number of Cycles * Staff Hourly Cost) + (Value of Auditability) Example: Creates a single, auditable system for all document reviews. Eliminates version control problems and confusion about feedback. Accelerates the review cycle by sending parallel requests and automated reminders.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Document-Centric Workflow

This is a document-centric workflow in SharePoint.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Configure SharePoint: In your document library settings, enable "Content approval for submitted items."
  2. Build the Flow: Use the trigger When a file is created or modified (properties only). Add a trigger condition to only run when the Approval Status is "Pending." Add logic to look up the required approvers. Use the Start and wait for an approval action. Use a Condition to check the outcome. If "Approve," use the Set content approval status action. Provide comments from the approval action in the Comments field.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Handle multiple versions. By default, uploading a new version of a document will trigger the flow again. The flow can be enhanced to first check if there is an existing approval process running for that document. If so, it can automatically cancel the old approval process and start a new one, notifying the original approvers that a new version is available for their review.

catalogue.title: Employee Suggestion Box
catalogue.miniDescription: Create a transparent and engaging system for capturing, evaluating, and actioning employee ideas for process improvements and cost savings.
catalogue.problem: A warehouse operator has a simple idea that could save 10 minutes on every shift. He doesn't know who to tell, so the idea is lost and the inefficiency continues.
catalogue.value: Employees are a fantastic source of innovative ideas for process improvements, cost savings, and new products. A traditional suggestion box (physical or email-based) often feels like a black hole where ideas disappear. This solution creates a transparent and engaging system for capturing, evaluating, and actioning employee ideas.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in innovation and engagement. Formula: Value = (Value of Implemented Ideas) + (Value of Increased Employee Engagement) Example: Fosters a culture of innovation and continuous improvement. Unlocks potentially significant cost savings and efficiency gains from front-line employees. Boosts morale by showing employees that their ideas are valued and considered.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: A Lifecycle for Ideas

This solution creates a full lifecycle for ideas.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Build the Intake Form: Create a simple Power App or Form for idea submission.
  2. Set up the SharePoint Tracker: Create a list to be the master repository for all ideas and their current status.
  3. Build the Flow: Trigger from the form submission. Use the Teams Post message in a chat or channel action. Use the SharePoint Create item action to log the idea. Use Send an email (V2) or Post an adaptive card to assign the review task. Create a second flow, triggered When an item is modified on the tracker list, to handle the status update notifications.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Create a monthly "Idea of the Month" digest. A scheduled flow can run at the end of each month, find all the ideas that were marked as "Implemented," and use an AI Builder prompt to generate a summary of the month's innovations. This summary can be sent in a company-wide email, celebrating the implemented ideas and their creators.

catalogue.title: Facilities Management & Service Requests
catalogue.miniDescription: Provide a simple, centralized system for employees to report facilities issues and for the management team to track them to resolution.
catalogue.problem: An employee in the Zurich office notices that a ceiling tile is loose and looks unsafe. He mentions it to his manager, who makes a mental note to email the facilities team but gets distracted and forgets. The safety hazard remains unaddressed.
catalogue.value: Every physical office space generates a constant stream of service requests: a lightbulb is out, a room is too cold, a coffee machine is broken. Managing these requests via email or word-of-mouth is inefficient and lacks traceability. This solution provides a simple, centralized system for employees to report facilities issues and for the management team to track them to resolution.
catalogue.roi: The ROI is measured in efficiency and safety. Formula: Value = (Value of Safety/Security Incidents Avoided) + (Admin Hours Saved * Hourly Cost) Example: Provides a simple, transparent, and efficient process for managing all facilities requests. Ensures that no request, especially a safety-related one, is ever lost or forgotten. Creates a valuable data set for the facilities team to analyze trends and identify recurring problems.
catalogue.implementationGuide:
The Solution Blueprint: An Internal Ticketing Solution

This is a classic internal ticketing and triage solution.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guide
  1. Set up Planner: Create a new plan in Microsoft Planner called "Facilities Requests." Create different buckets for different locations or request types (e.g., "Zurich Office," "Geneva Office").
  2. Build the Power App: Create a simple canvas app for submitting requests. Use the Office 365 Users connector to automatically get the user's location.
  3. Build the Intake Flow: Trigger the flow from the Power App. Use the Planner Create a task action. Use a Switch control on the Request Type or Location to assign the task to the correct person. Use the Outlook or Teams connector to send a confirmation to the requester.
  4. Build the Completion Flow: Create a second flow using the trigger When a task is completed in Planner. Use this flow to look up the original requester (you can store their email in the task description) and send them the final "resolved" notification.
Beyond the Basics (Pro-Tip)

Integrate with vendor systems. For issues that require an external contractor, the Power Automate flow can use an AI Builder prompt to generate a formal work order summary from the user's request. It can then automatically forward this summary to the vendor's ticketing system via email or API, creating a seamless link between your internal request and the external service provider.
